On which the beams of honour proudly ſmile!
Thy clarion breathe its ſacred ſound,
The ſon to emulate a glorious ſire!

div.head: SCENE IV.—A plantation walk near the battlements of the caſtle.—Moonlight.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: If d'ye zee I'd know'd there was but only he, I zhould not have thought it worth while to vetch ſo many zoldiers for one rogue. Certain, howzever, I've placed the whole tribe of the Switz guards at the foot of the mountain.—But, mum, Robin, not a zyllable about the zoldier volk, for fear my lady ſhou'd be angry.

sp.speaker: Miſs Som.
sp.p: And what does the ruffian ſay for himſelf, Robin?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Why, an' pleaſe you, my lady, he zays but little—but as I took a peep at'n thro' the iron lattice, he zeem'd to pay it away wi' thinking!

sp.speaker: Miſs Som.
sp.p: I hope you let him want for nothing?

sp.speaker: 'Robin.
sp.p: 'Oh, no my lady; I took'n two ribs of roaſt beef, and a zlice of baked pudding myzelf—but the zulky toad woud 'na feed.'

sp.speaker: 'Miſs Som.
sp.p: 'Poor wretch—perhaps he may be unwell.'

sp.speaker: 'Robin.
sp.p: 'Unwell?—oh, he's a rum little chap!—but he ſhall give me my dry coat back again, howzever—When I clapp'd the beef down on the ztool before 'n, what now, my lady, do you think the cunning rogue zaid?—Iz thiz the way you treat your ztate prizoners, zays he—virzt and voremozt to take away their ztomachs, and then to zet good cheer before 'n?'

sp.speaker: 'Miſs Som.
sp.p: 'Well, Nerinda!'

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.p: 'He'll confeſs nothing, ma'am, but that curioſity compell'd him to play this device upon Robin.'

sp.speaker: 'Robin.
sp.p: 'Yez, gad rat 'n!'

sp.speaker: 'Miſs Som.
sp.p: 'Of what country is he?'

sp.speaker: 'Ner.
sp.p: 'I believe he's an Engliſhman.'

sp.speaker: 'Miſs Som.
sp.p: 'Some poor frantic wanderer—enquire of him further, and anon I'll ſee him myſelf.'

sp.speaker: 'Robin.
sp.p: 'Lord, my lady, hez as cunning a little villain, with a tongue—'

sp.speaker: 'Ner.
sp.p: 'As nimble as your own. Come, follow me.'

sp.speaker: 'Miſs Som.
sp.p: 'Calm is this parting ſcene of nature—how ſoft her whiſpers of repoſe! Even the voice of ſorrow now is ſtill, ſave from that lovelorn bird, whoſe ſtrains I hear.'

lg.l: Still let thy plaintive numbers flow,
Sweet bird of ſolitude and night,
And I will join the ſong of woe,
Until the morn's returning light.
With thee I'll ſhun the world's relief,
Woo ſorrow only to my breaſt,
And preſs, for luxury of grief,
The thorn, that will not let it reſt!

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.p: Oh dear, ma'am, a body of armed men, no doubt the whole gang, are halted towards the weſt tower.

sp.speaker: Miſs Som.
sp.p: Impoſſible! and in a country ſo fam'd for peace and freedom?

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.p: Indeed, and indeed its true!

sp.speaker: Miſs Som.
sp.p: Tho' few in number, let our domeſtics then inſtantly arm!

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.p: But what ſhall we do with our priſoner?

sp.speaker: Miſs Som.
sp.p: Order him in the front of the battlement, as a fit ſacrifice to the lawleſs rage of his confederates. Let us even forget the weakneſs of our ſex, and arm ourſelves, Nerinda.

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.p: Oh dear, ma'am, you wont pretend to fight: what can ſuch helpleſs creatures as we do?

sp.speaker: Miſs Som.
sp.p: Wonders, in a juſt cauſe! at leaſt, Nerinda, we can expoſe to abhorrence that ſavage licentiouſneſs, which even women are compell'd to reſiſt.

sp.speaker: 'Ner.
sp.p:
'How unfortunate, as well as alarming—for this is the very time I was to admit
my good natured mountain acquaintance:—and why not even now, when we ſtand more in need of a gallant man than ever!'

div.head: SCENE V.—The Abbey Gate.
div.stage: Enter Comte FRIPONI diſguiſed, with FREEBOOTERS.

sp.speaker: 'Comte.
sp.p: 'De place of rendezvous—it was luck I meet la petite fille de chambre!—Attendez—ven I go in—keep cloſe to my perſon, for fear of me ſurprize.'

sp.speaker: '1ſt Freebooter.
sp.p: 'We'll follow your honour cloſe, rely upon it.'

sp.speaker: 'Comte.
sp.p: 'For why ſhe not appear?—prenez garde—voila, le diable Anglois!'

lg.l: Love may lead my ſteps aſtray;
Where, ah where's ma jolie fille?
Come, and ſafely point the way,
Wont you? Yes, I'm ſure you will!
Let me not in vain implore,
Hither fly, ma jolie fille,
Open then the garden door,
Wont you?—yes I'm ſure you will,

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: This is ſtrange! I muſt have miſtaken the gate, for why ſhould ſhe deceive me?

div.stage: Enter LOPEZ, and CAZELL with drawn ſwords, and ſoon after a file of Swiſs Soldiery.

sp.speaker: Cazell, Lopez, Dalton, & Robin.
sp.l: Yield, cruel monſters! vengeance dread!
Which way can the reſt be fled?

sp.speaker: Miſs Som.
sp.l: Calmly I to fate reſign!

sp.speaker: Cazell, &c.
sp.l: Hear the wailing voice to woe.

sp.speaker: Soldiers.
sp.l: Advance! 'tis a ſoldier's duty.
To ſave, not to plunder beauty,
Where e'er he's doom'd to go.

sp.speaker: Miſs Som.
sp.l: Take this wretched life of mine!

sp.speaker: Comte, and others.
sp.l: Let us out before it's night.

sp.speaker: Robin,
sp.l: That I will not by this light.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: When 'tis woman that inſpires us,
Valour,
Honor,
Glory, fires us.

sp.speaker: Cazell, and others.
sp.l: Hear the lovely ſufferers cry?

sp.speaker: Comte, &c.
sp.l: Let us once more daylight ſpy?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.l: Hold your tongues and quiet lye.

sp.speaker: Soldiers, &c.
sp.l: Knaves, if here we cannot view you,
O'er the Mountains we'll purſue you.

sp.speaker: Comte, &c.
sp.l: Let us once more daylight ſpy?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.l: Hold your tongues once more ſay I.

sp.speaker: Soldiers, &c.
sp.l: Since the ruffians wont appear,
March on!

sp.speaker: Miſs Somerville.
sp.l: Behold your victim here![Throwing open the door, diſcovers herſelf.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Miſs Somerville!

sp.speaker: Miſs Som.
sp.p: Impoſſible! and arm'd againſt my life?—

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Oh no! led hither by our better ſtars to defend the perſon of her, who too unkindly fled from his protection!

sp.speaker: Miſs Som.
sp.p: Am I to believe thoſe ſenſes which have ſo cruelly deceived me?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Why, dear heart, my Lady, this is the ſtrange Gentleman that wou'd a vit for dear life to defend you.

sp.speaker: Miſs Som.
sp.p: And do I find in Dalton my gallant defender? (Dalton talks apart with her.)

sp.speaker: Swiſs Serj.
sp.p: Advance! (to his men.)

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Now dont'e fight no more about my blunders; for I vancy they be all vriends and neighbours, except a few rogues that I a' got ſnug in a corner.

sp.speaker: Miſs Som.
sp.p: Why, are not theſe our rude aſſailants whom I ſaw from the Battlement?

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: We are guards of the Republic, Lady, marched here to preſerve it's peace, and the property of this Caſtle.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: All this is wond'rous ſtrange!

sp.speaker: Miſs Som.
sp.p: How came I thus deceived?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Why, my lady, it was all along o' I! for when that comical chap ſtript me, and got the key of the drawbridge, I took'n for one o' the Mountain robbers that I dreamt on laſt Sunday, who like a rogue, meant to let in all his comrades; zo what did I, but run and vetch theſe honeſt zoldier gentry to zave you from murder, or mayhap zomewhat worſe.

sp.speaker: Miſs Som.
sp.p: Your zeal rather outran your diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: But it was faithfully intended.

sp.speaker: Miſs Som.
sp.p: Come, Charles, attend me now in ſearch of a moſt amiable, and affectionate companion.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: What doings does he mean?

sp.speaker: Cazell.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe, Miſs, de rejoice, and firework we hear juſt now.

sp.speaker: Lady Phil.
sp.p: Fireworks! I am ſorry he informed them of my coming, I ſhould like to have been received incog; without any particular regard to my rank or diſtinction! but come, which is the entrée, Daniel?

sp.speaker: Daniel.
sp.p: Stop a little, my lady, and in the midſt of the buſtle; I'll try to ſtep down, and let you all in, if I die for it!

sp.speaker: Cazell.
sp.p: Surely the fellow's mad, Lopez.

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: Oh, no, only bewitched, I ſuppoſe, like the reſt of the caſtle.
sp.stage: [Exeunt over the drawbridge into the caſtle.

div.head: SCENE VII.—Veſtibule within the caſtle.

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.p: Oh! it was all my unfortunate doing! I found out my miſtake, juſt time, enough to fly and force my poor lady, out of their barbarous reach for a moment! Beſet by a hoſt without, and aſſail'd by ruffians within, what hope I of protecting her further?

sp.speaker: 1ſt. Freebooter.
sp.p: Softly, comrade! here ſhe is, and luckily all alone!

sp.speaker: 2nd. Freebooter.
sp.p: Why then, no ceremony.

div.stage: (Draw their ſwords, Nerinda obſerving them ſhrieks)

sp.speaker: 1ſt Freebooter.
sp.p: No uproar, madam, I charge you, to diſturb the peace of the manſion.

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.p: What is it you would have? (they ſeize her.)

sp.speaker: 2nd Freebooter.
sp.p: The pleaſure of conveying you, and all your valuables into our mountain for protection, fair lady of the caſtle, that's all!

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.p: Lady of the caſtle! indeed, indeed! gentlemen, you are much miſtaken—I am only an humble domeſtic, and therefore every way unworthy of the honour you intend me!

sp.speaker: 1ſt Freebooter.
sp.p: This inſtant then, ſhew us where ſhe is, and all her treaſure.

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.p: Something leſs than that, gentlemen, I hope will appeaſe you?

sp.speaker: 2nd Freebooter.
sp.p: No—diſpatch!

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.p: (aſide) The monſter that ſo deceived me!

sp.speaker: Comte.
sp.p: Eh bien, ma petite guide! vite! vite! my mules are at de gate to car votre maitreſſe, yourſelf, and all your treaſure to mon chatteau!

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.p: But, Sir, as I had the honour to introduce you, indulge me at leaſt in one ſmall requeſt!

sp.speaker: Comte.
sp.p: Oh, certainment qu'eſt que ca?

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.p: Only, Sir, as they are of ſuch conſiderable value, that you will have the goodneſs to take charge of my poor lady's jewels yourſelf!

sp.speaker: Comte.
sp.p: Aſſurement! and de lady auſſi, if ſhe be prett comme vous! (aſide) Oh, quelle grand coup! ſhew me to de dear creature dis moment!

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.p: Up this ſtaircaſe of the tower, is an antichamber to the right—there, alas! too ſoon you'll find her!

sp.speaker: Comte.
sp.p: Wid de jewels, and beaucoup de l'argent?

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.p: Alas! all!

sp.speaker: Comte.
sp.p: Bon! come, you ſhew de way allons!

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.p: Not a word, I entreat you, Sir, that you were directed by me.

sp.speaker: Comte.
sp.p: (making ſignals of ſecrecy) Oh! jamais! jamais!
sp.stage: (Exit thro' the ſtair caſe door with Freebooters, Nerinda ſoon after haſtily returns, and bolts it.)

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.p: There, monſter, I have out generall'd you for the preſent, however; where now is my faithful countryman?

div.p: Oh, Robin! I'm glad you're come!

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Fleſh and blood cannot hold out this way much longer!

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.p: Courage, man, I have ſecured three of the ring leaders within here!

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: But pray ye madam Nerinda, how did you contrive to nab them ſo nicely?

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.p: Why, as they ſtumbled up the old dark ſtaircaſe, in ſearch of my lady and her jewels, I turned the bolt, and have them all ſafe together.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Ecod you nick'd 'em there for once, howzever.

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.p: Now you muſt guard the door, without ſaying one word to any body about it, till I return with ſuccour.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: But how mun I manage to keep three ſuch deſperate toads, only under two bolts? I'll try my beſt howzever, till you get more help.

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.p: Ay, do, my honeſt Robin.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Ecod, then it's lucky enough I've juſt let in the Zwiſs Guard; come now what will, my Lady cannot blame me for vetching 'em, for there's a Banditti zure enough, in the Caſtle now, or the devil's in't. (liſtens at the door) The chaps do zeem pretty quiet tho' in their new lodgings, and they'd beſt keep zo (levelling the blunderbuſs at the door) I be not over fond of your deviliſh pop-guns, vor they lay many a vine fellow flat before he's on his guard. If I'd had but my quarter-ſtaff from the weſt, I'd a crack'd moſt of their noddles myſelf before this time, or know'd the reaſon why—ecod here comes another on 'em!

div.stage: Enter DALTON, with a drawn hanger.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Which way could the ruffians fly?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Now dont'e come no nigher, or I mun down wi ye!

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Why, how is all this?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: (looking at him earneſtly) Dear heart and zo you be! our true Engliſh friend that paſſed me juſt now, and ax'd ſo kindly about the poor Ladies.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Where are the ſuffering captives? (Robin points to the Tower door behind him.) Confin'd within that Tower; let me inſtantly behold them!

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Can't—I be zet, d'ye zee, as guard over 'en; zo neither vriend nor voe ſhall let 'en out! beſides you're but a youngſter, and they'd be too many for you all to nothing. (noiſe without) The devils own-zelf be in them zurely! vor here's two more! now mun we ztand ztout by one another.

sp.speaker: Comte.
sp.p: Ah! ah! ſhe no come to Monſieur Anglois! now I try my canto bello!

lg.l: None as me do love you more,
Cara bella—jolie fille!
Open den de abbey door,
Vont you? ah! by gar you vill,
Cara bella—jolie fille!

div.stage: (Nerinda opens the gate, and making ſigns, the Comte and Freebooters entering, follow her.)

div.head: SCENE VI.—The Battlements of the Caſtle.
div.stage: Miſs Somerville appearing on one wing, Daniel and domeſtics on another. A file of Swiſs ſoldiery in Front.—Platoon firing heard.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.l: The Caſtle quick ſurrender,
Ye horde of Mountaineers;
Or elſe our arms ſhall raze it
By ſtorm around your ears.

sp.speaker: Miſs Som.
sp.l: Of pride you can't diſarm me;
So hence, ye ruffian crew!
No ſummons ſhall alarm me!
Nor tyrant force ſubdue. (EXIT.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.l: Are you for war?

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: No—peace my trade is.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.l: Then will you yield?

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Nay, aſk the ladies.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.l: Your walls we muſt batter down.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Not yet, Sir, I pray!

sp.speaker: Domeſtic.
sp.l: You'll waſte, thus your powder,

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Your ſhot throw away!

sp.speaker: Full Chorus.
sp.l: Honour bids us prove victorious.
Juſtice bids us prove victorious.
Courage bids us prove victorious.
To repel them, wou'd be glorious!
To ſubdue them, wou'd be glorious!

sp.speaker: Serjeant.
sp.l: Gunners, now your mortars bring,
To aſſail the Eaſtern wing.

sp.speaker: Daniel.
sp.l: Hark ye, Sir,—in pity ſpare,

sp.speaker: Serſeant.
sp.l: Mercy none of you muſt ſhare.

sp.speaker: Daniel.
sp.l: She who fights, and looks ſo fair!

sp.speaker: Full Chorus.
sp.l: Honour, juſtice, &c.

sp.speaker: Dan,
sp.p: I'm glad they're all marched off to the other ſide of the caſtle! I'll ſtay here and take breath a little! I only turned my back on the cowardly dogs for a minute, and ſpank they had me in an awkward place.
There—ſhe's at it again pell mell? (looking out anxiouſly) Eh! yes, but it is—my dear Lady coming! and my deliverance I hope along with her!

div.stage: Enter Lady PHILIPPA, JULIA, LOPEZ and CAZELL.

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: Yes, yes, we are right enough—for ſee your ladyſhip's truſty courier on the battlement.

sp.speaker: Lady Phil.
sp.p: Looking out to announce our arrival! I hope we are not too late, Daniel?

sp.speaker: Daniel.
sp.p: Oh! no, my Lady, you're time enough to have a ſhare of it. Here have been warm doings, I promiſe you!

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Now, Mr. Serjeant, only be you zo good as to mount guard a little at this door—and I'll vetch you a bottle or two of old Engliſh ſtingo to whet your whiſkers with!—'after that we'll rummage the ſtair-caſe, when madam Nerinda comes, and zee whether we a got vriends, or foes there; vor we've been at ſuch croſs purpoſes o' late, that I don't know which they may turn out after all.'—One thing now, however's zertain—that my lady's old zweet heart be come to vetch her home—zo I'll go and let our Madge out of the cellar, and bid her pack up her duds for Old England!

lg.l: Acroſs the briny zeas I'll zteer,
And back to Taunton Dean,
To tell the little huzzies there,
The zights that I ha zeen!
Oh rare be the doings of Taunton Dean! O rare, &c.
When I zet out for voreign parts,
Poor zouls, how they did cry!
I thought they wou'd ha' broke their hearts,
They were zo fond o'I!
O ſad were the doings of Taunton Dean! O ſad, &c.
If they could cry when I were gone
In grief for zuch a boy.
Why zure, when I goes back a mon
They'll cry again for joy!
Oh rare be the doings of Taunton Dean! Oh rare, &c.
My zunday zpouſe poor Madge I'll make,
As vree as vlow'rs in May,
And from the little jades I'll take
A wife for every day!
O rare then the doings of Taunton Dean! Oh rare, &c.

div.head: SCENE VIII.—The antient Hall, illuminated and decorated with banners, and armorial bearings.
div.stage: Lady PHILIPPA, Miſs SOMERVILLE, and DALTON

sp.speaker: Lady Phil.
sp.p: You have told me many ſtrange things to be ſure, child; but reſpecting the feudal inheritance of this caſtle, I fancy I know a little more than you. Indeed, how you became its reſident at all, is matter of great ſurprize to me.

sp.speaker: Miſs Som.
sp.p: To receive your ladyſhip within its walls on any terms, is an honour I little expected.

sp.speaker: 'Lady Phil.
sp.p: 'I always ſaid that you and Dalton wou'd come together; and a very decent alliance for two young families on both ſides—you cou'd not deceive me, child.'

sp.speaker: 'Miſs Som.
sp.p: 'No, Lady Philippa; I fear that I have been too buſily employed in deceiving myſelf.'

sp.speaker: Lady Phil.
sp.p: (Taking her glaſs, and looking round the Hall.) Let me contemplate the antient banners, and armorial bearings! near this ſpot, no doubt, the gallant Knight of Charlemagne, true to his plighted vow, fell in the preſence of a beloved miſtreſs
and honourably died!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Fit ſcene for a more humble KNIGHT of Love, to claim the hand of her—for whom he fondly lives!

sp.speaker: Lady Phil.
sp.p: I'm all amazement! Dorimond!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Dear madam, allow me to declare, that tho' I knew not of Dorimond's diſguiſe, my heart, adopting his ſentiments, naturally triumphs in its ſucceſs!

sp.speaker: 'Dalton.
sp.p: 'Oh, your ladyſhip will excuſe it all, when you obſerve, that the rogue, Dorimond, has deceived even me, his beſt friend, by the metamorphoſis.—Now Louiſa, I truſt you behold Miſs Sidney in her real character.'

sp.speaker: Miſs Som.
sp.p: I do—as a rival created only by own ſuſpicions.
sp.stage: [Miſs Som. Julia, Dalton and Dorimond, talk apart.

sp.speaker: Lady Phil.
sp.p: Who waits? where is my guide, Lopez!

sp.speaker: Cazell.
sp.p: I left him, my lady, in the courtyard, paying due reſpect to the Count Friponi.

sp.speaker: Lady Phil.
sp.p: The Comte?—oh, I'm rejoiced that he is arrived!

sp.speaker: 'Dalton.
sp.p: 'What, my chaunting, woman-killing hero?'

sp.speaker: 'Cazell.
sp.p: 'Why, do you know this vaunting braggart, Charles?'

sp.speaker: 'Dalton.
sp.p: 'Perfectly!'

sp.speaker: Lady Phil.
sp.p: But where is he? I'm impatient to welcome his arrival.

sp.speaker: Cazell.
sp.p: He's in his own apartments, my lady, but rather in a diſhabille.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: I'm ſorry this wretch is return'd to torment us.

sp.speaker: Miſs Som.
sp.p: What can all this mean? (aſide to Cazell.)

sp.speaker: Cazell.
sp.p: Why, ma'am, the plain matter of fact is, that like other great men, ſome of the Count's enterprizes have miſcarried: his laſt deſign was to diſpoſſeſs you of this caſtle; but failing in this attempt, he has modeſty enough, as a freebooter, to put up with one of its dungeons!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: The leader of the banditti!

sp.speaker: Lady Phil.
sp.p: The Count diſgraced, and in a dungeon? Oh, that Mr. Sidney were returned! (aſide.) Lopez ſhall inſtantly depart for Straſburgh!

sp.speaker: Cazell.
sp.p: On what errand, my lady?

sp.speaker: Lady Phil.
sp.p: In ſearch of Mr. Sidney, the only perſon in whom I can ſafely confide.

div.stage: Enter SIDNEY in his own dreſs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sidney.
sp.p: A ſingle wiſh of your's reſtores him back to happineſs, as well as ſight!— (Lifts up his bandeau.)

sp.speaker: Lady Phil.
sp.p: I am petrified, aſtoniſhed, and every way deceived.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sidney.
sp.p: Not ſo my Lady Philippa, if I have at laſt but the good fortune to prove—the man to your mind!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Mr. Sidney!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: My dear father in faithful Lopez!

sp.speaker: 'Mr. Sidney.
sp.p: 'Where's the wonder, Lady Philippa, that I, an old friend, ſhould have procured you a more truſty guide than your new faſhion'd acquaintance?'

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: And can it be poſſible, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sidney.
sp.p: Yes, your fellow-ſervant in diſguiſe.—But once or twice, young ſpark, we had nearly been too cunning for each other.

sp.speaker: 'Dalton.
sp.p: 'You have contrived Sir, to hit off an admirable character in this travelling maſquerade.'

sp.speaker: 'Lady Phil.
sp.p: 'The ſhaft of ridicule has reached me. I perceive but too late, that to perſiſt, even in a family prejudice, is unworthy of a great, or a good mind.'

sp.speaker: 'Mr. Sidney.
sp.p:
'(Taking her by the hand) Oh, never too late to renounce an error, which an amiable
heart muſt have long diſclaim'd! This billet, which I confeſs to have peruſed, has removed all my ſerious apprehenſions. I return it, therefore, as an harmleſs, tho' unguarded document of faſhionable levity.'

sp.speaker: Mr. Sidney.
sp.p: Twice has this gallant adventurer ſaved our only child: join with me then, Lady Philippa, in beſtowing her hand upon him, and thus ſecure the faithful ſervices of an honeſt fellow thro' life.

sp.speaker: Lady Phil.
sp.p: Moſt chearfully.

sp.speaker: Dori.
sp.p: How ſhall I ever repay—

sp.speaker: Mr. Sidney.
sp.p: Not by long ſpeeches, Dorimond—You have won her by no feats of anceſtry, but your own natural deſerts; if ſhe prove a bleſſing therefore, long may you live to wear it.

sp.speaker: Lady Phil.
sp.p: Oh! Mr. Sidney, you have taught me at length to feel, that to contribute to the happineſs of thoſe around us, is far more honourable than all the pomp that heraldry can boaſt.

sp.speaker: 'Mr. Sidney.
sp.p: 'Then have I neither toil'd, nor travell'd in vain!'

sp.speaker: Sir Leinſter.
sp.p: I perceive you generally contrive that Sir Leinſter ſhou'd be front rank, where there's a priſon; and always in the rear, when there's either love, or fair fighting! But I'm in luck that the Comte has got his deſerts, tho' I have loſt mine! And what a mighty pretty ſiege you have had, where you've mann'd all your works with women! (looking at Miſs Som.) 'Palliluh! why, is the devil's ſelf come to you all, that you ladies ſhou'd turn ſoldiers, and your lacquies become fine gentlemen? I dare ſay, now, it's all very funny, if one could but find out the reaſon why?'

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: O yes, Sir, I've heard of all your pranks, and find I am the only ſufferer, by keeping my own countenance.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sidney.
sp.p: All ſhall be explained, Sir Leinſter, to your ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: But its time we muſter our little garriſon, to get a return of our miſſing, and wounded.

sp.speaker: Lady Phil.
sp.p: Where is poor Daniel?

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.p: Having properly diſpoſed of the ruffianly Comte, who baſely ſurprized me, I thought in my duty to adminiſter the beſt comfort in my power to one, who has ſuffered a little too ſeverely from his own curioſity, and my miſtake.

sp.speaker: Daniel.
sp.p: You have an odd way here of rewarding merit, that's certain; for you open your gates to a banditti, and throw your beſt friends, neck and heels into a dungeon!

sp.speaker: Miſs Som.
sp.p: 'And is this your arch valet, that put us all in ſuch a fright?'

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: 'The very ſame; and as inoffenſive a creature as ever breath'd.'

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: 'What a rare thing my curioſity has prov'd to all except myſelf! It was rather hard, after eſcaping the caniſter-ſhot of theſe ladies tongues, to be ſtuck upon the battlements, to be pelted with double-round, and grape!'

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: 'Poor creature!'

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Where are you wounded, Daniel?

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: Not where its likely to disfigure me much, my lady—being as it were—in a place a little out of ſight!

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: We'll find the means of a ſpeedy cure; but you don't ſeem to recollect your old friends, Dan?

sp.speaker: Miſs Som.
sp.p: But here, Dalton, I owe more than I can expreſs. (points to Ner.)

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: I am much her debtor alſo; for ſhe was the guiding ſtar, that led me, a diſconſolate wanderer, to this ſpot.

sp.speaker: Miſs Som.
sp.p: 'Is that ſo, Nerinda?'

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.p: 'Nearly, Ma'am, and one time or other, perhaps you may do me as good a turn.'

sp.speaker: Miſs Som.
sp.p: 'The day ſeems to have been devoted to ſtrange myſteries, and as the night is too far advanc'd to allow of your departure, I truſt the new poſſeſſor of this caſtle will allow me to give you welcome.'

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Moſt welcome all! for thus our lovely hoſteſs bids me ſay; and though we have no feats of chivalry to boaſt, we may, at leaſt, as goodnatured travellers, amuſe ourſelves with recounting our various adventures.

sp.speaker: Sir Lein.
sp.p: But when you do that, you'll remember, if you pleaſe, to forget mine.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Firſt accept my open recantation! for here do I renounce the vain parade, and follies of falſe grandeur, convinced, that the juſt diſtinctions of honourable rank, are beſt ſupported by their own intrinſic merit!

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Then am I raiſed to the enviable dignity of a happy man. Come, you young deſtined brides, ere you ſet out on your nuptial travels, will you deign to accept of a hint from one, who has gone this crooked road before you?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Certainly, Sir.

sp.speaker: Miſs Som.
sp.p: Oh, with pleaſure!

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Then build not too much on converting a man into a huſband, unleſs you can condeſcend at the ſame time—to create that huſband your GUIDE thro' life!

sp.speaker: CHORUS.—
sp.l: Now let us ſeek our native coaſt,
Where friends we hope will meet us;
As Travellers we then may boaſt,
If they but kindly greet us.

sp.speaker: QUARTETTO.—DALTON, DORIMOND, MISS SOMERVILLE, and JULIA.
sp.l: Let others travel worlds around
For pleaſure if they chooſe it;
The road to happineſs we've found,
And hope no more to loſe it.

sp.speaker: NERINDA.
sp.l: To follow cloſe your ſteps thro' life,
You know, dear Ma'am, I meant it;
So ſhou'd I follow as a wiſe,
I'm ſure I ſhan't repent it.

sp.speaker: CHORUS.
sp.l: —Now let us ſeek, &c.

sp.speaker: DANIEL.
sp.l: Come, little Dan, 'twixt you and me,
Your trip may well content ye;
You've loſt your curioſity,
And that is gain in plenty.

sp.speaker: MR. SIDNEY.
sp.l: By travel I've regain'd a wife,
Tho' I was forc'd to ſnare her;
So, for the remnant of my life,
I hope to win, and wear her.

sp.speaker: FULL CHORUS,
sp.l: Now let us ſeek our native coaſt,
Where friends we hope will meet us;
As Travellers we then may boaſt,
If they but kindly greet us!
